course.subject: CIVL
course.name: Big History, Sustainability and Climate Change
course.description: Big History as an emerging interdisciplinary framework, provides a long term perspective to see the world through reconstructing the history from the big bang all the way to the present. In such a longer time scale, overview of stars, planetary and species evolution, as well as concepts in climate change and how it is related to sustainability of the planet's environment for its current inhabitants, including humanity, will be discussed. The physical science basis, impacts, risk, mitigation and adaptation measures of climate change will also be investigated (including technical and social solutions). For local and regional vulnerabilities, such as extreme weather events, sea-levels rise, storm surge and coastal flooding, will be covered. The significance of collective learning under the big history framework, both as a driver for our exponentially growing impacts, as well as for better solutions, will be highlighted.

reviews.author: maize
reviews.comment_content:
The whole course is about Big History and all the lectures basically explains the same idea, things are always changing and it is human who needs to be saved, not the planet as the Earth have so many years prior to human's existence.

The difference lectures gives further details with different examples, like the Big Bang, evolution of organisms, the rise of civilization etc.

If you are looking for concrete concepts and knowledge, then this class may not be very suitable for you but it is still nice to learn about different facts about the Earth and human beings.

There are 3 group discussions followed by short responses, 1 10-pages essay and 1 poster & video group project throughout the whole course. He would usually look for answers that are more like a liberal studies answer than answers with facts and numbers.

Also there is no final exam for the course, so the mid-term exam and the assignments are very important.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It is quite hard to concentrate during the class (maybe it's because it's a 9am lecture), but Alexis would upload lecture videos to Canvas regularly so it is ok miss some lessons.

Alexis is quite friendly to the students after class but during class he had little to no effort in making the class more interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
I am not sure about the grading distribution this semester nor did I know my own scores of all the assignments and exam, he just gave a grade at the end of semester.

But as far as I can see (from my results and my classmates), he gave out pretty good grading. I heard a lot of people got A range.

The grading system is like what Bor (the previous review) had said and it's not transparent at all.
reviews.comment_workload: Not too much workload to be frank. The 'busiest' time in this course is when you need to hand in the 10-page essay. But it is just repeating what you have handed in the previous assignments and poster in addition to lengthening it to more pages.

reviews.author: whitewhale
reviews.comment_content: Big history (I recommend learning through crash course), sustainability (conceptual), and climate change (some stats occupying 1/30 of the slides). But all the ideas are closely linked so if there is enough time try to read everything and say attention in class to get a concrete and clear picture of the whole message Alexis is trying to deliver.
reviews.comment_teaching: Alexis is famous for his long-winded lectures lol, I wouldn't doubt his ability to lengthen a 1-hour lecture into 3 without having a break. And he is dragged away and distracted a lot of the times so don't expect some intense lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: Alexis is super generous in grading, even if you screwed the mid term up (going-a-bit-below-mean-screwed, that is, not hitting-the-minimum-screwed), you still get a high chance of getting a B. I scored maximum (96 out of 100) in the midterm, 4.5 out of 5 in the first essay, they did not let us know our performance in other assignments, and at last I got an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: An MC midterm, 2 short essays concluding 2 in-class discussions, one group project (a 5-min video, an A3 poster), and a long 10-page essay about the course. you'll be doing everything except the midterm with the same bunch of people, a 4-people group all assigned by Alexis, he likes to mix people of different background together, i.e. different year of study, major, nationality, etc.

reviews.author: KKKKK
reviews.comment_content:
The course tries to introduce big history which is an emerging academic discipline, and later try to explain and understand climate change under the big history perspective.
Big History is basically a subject trying to combine efforts from different disciplines so to provide a multidisciplinary view of the issue. It covers major changing events since big bang till now like star formation, solar system formation, first life on Earth, etc...
With so much in the past, the course aims at allowing students to see the bigger picture of an issue (climate change) using the big history perspective.
Some of the course content is to some extent interesting to know about, for example, Alexis mentioned 99.9% of the species had gone extinct in the course of history and normally a specie live for around a million years. It's something you can search online to learn about but normally you won't.
reviews.comment_teaching: Alexis is not a particularly good teacher because his teaching is really boring + it is a 9 a.m class this semester. Normally there will be less than 30 students in class out of the total of 94 of them. He is somewhat passionate in teaching and he is quite nice to students who raise a question, though you might not get the answer you expected.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 individual assignments: each 10%
Mid-term: 35%
Poster presentation: 10-25%
Term paper: 10-25%
The poster and the term paper contribute to a total of 35% of the total course grade and student can decide how to split the weighting between the two assignments.
The grading system is not transparent, no score is revealed throughout the entire semester. The only thing you get is the letter grade in SIS.
A range: 22.8%
B range: 48.5%
C-F range: 28.7% (given by past statistics from Alexis)
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite high. The 3 individual assignments with each at most 3 pages. He is quite casual with the assignments and you can submit a mind map instead of an essay.
The mid-term is basically a final scheduled at late April covering everything in the course, it is all MC and T/F questions with mark deduction for wrong answers. It asks about something like what's the CO2 level before the industrial period so remembering every content in the notes will get you high marks.
Poster comes with a video presentation of 3-5 minutes, the link of the video should be placed on the poster. Quite a lot of computer work so better team up with someone who is good at doing so.
Not much to say about the term paper except it's expected to be less than 10 pages.

reviews.author: Tuna
reviews.comment_content:
This course mainly divides into two parts, Big History and climate change.

When you look at course title you thought it is about climate change, however, half of the course is about big history which is the formation and evolution of earth.

Then it covers IPCC report. More on the figures of the effects on climate change. And not too much on the solutions. There is only like two to three lectures on that.

Alexis also invited some guest speaker for the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Alexis played so many videos in the lectures and the video are indeed so boring. Half of the class fall asleep and do other stuffs.

Some lectures you can jot down lots of things but some you cannot jot any.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not too bad, but don't expect that much.
There is no final exam. How you perform in the midterm really affects your grade a lot.
reviews.comment_workload:
Since there is only a mid-term and no final exam, you do not need to pay a lot of attention after mid-term.

In the Big History part, we needed to do a quiz after every chapter he taught, there is about 10 quizzes. But you can resubmit it as long as before the deadline. You just need to remember to do it and that's enough.

There is a group project which is a debate. Alexis will assign the group for you. Two groups will do a debate which is taped as a video for submission. Individual report is needed.

During the course, we need to write 2-3 short essays when Alexis wanted. Usually it is about one particular lecture or a topic he raised in class.
